title: Fluzone High-Dose Quad 2021-22 (PF) Intramuscular: Uses, Side Effects, Interactions, Pictures, Warnings & Dosing - WebMD
description: Find patient medical information for Fluzone High-Dose Quad 2021-22 (PF) intramuscular on WebMD including its uses, side effects and safety, interactions, pictures, warnings and user ratings.
cleaned_text: Uses This [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) is used to prevent infection by the [influenza](https://www.webmd.com/cold-and-flu/cold-or-flu-quiz) (" [flu](https://www.webmd.com/cold-and-flu/cold-or-flu-quiz)") virus. It is also called the seasonal [flu shot](https://www.webmd.com/cold-and-flu/fact-sheet-vaccines). Influenza can cause serious illness (rarely death), especially in people at high risk from the infection (such as young children, older adults, and people with chronic health problems). [Vaccines](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) work by causing the body to produce its own protection ( [antibodies](https://www.webmd.com/baby/antibody-testing)) against the virus.Vaccination is the best method for preventing infection and decreasing the seriousness of illness if you become infected. The brand and dose of [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/healthtool-childhood-immunizations-guide) you receive depends on your age. Influenza vaccination is not recommended in infants less than 6 months old.As with any vaccine, it may not fully protect everyone who receives it. Since different [types of flu](https://www.webmd.com/cold-and-flu/adult-flu-symptoms) viruses cause infection every flu season, usually a new vaccine is produced and given for each flu season.This [flu vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/cold-and-flu/fact-sheet-vaccines) does not contain live virus, so it cannot cause the flu. How to use Fluzone High-Dose Quad 2021-22 (PF) 240 Mcg/0.7 Ml IM Syringe Read all [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) information available from your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics) professional before receiving the [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/healthtool-childhood-immunizations-guide). If you have any questions, ask your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/video/what-is-the-aca) professional. The vaccine is usually given by injection into a muscle by a health care professional. Some brands may also be given by deep injection under the [skin](https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/skin-conditions-faq). Adults and children usually receive the injection in the upper arm, and infants receive it in the upper thigh. The vaccination is usually given in the time from September to November when the number of cases of [influenza](https://www.webmd.com/cold-and-flu/cold-or-flu-quiz) virus begins to increase (the start of " [flu](https://www.webmd.com/cold-and-flu/cold-or-flu-quiz) season"). Only one dose is required for people aged 9 years and older. Children under 9 years of age may receive a second dose depending on when the first dose was given. Discuss the dose schedule with your health care professional. Side Effects Soreness/redness/swelling/bruising at the injection site may occur and may last for up to 1-2 days. Fever, muscle aches, [headache](https://www.webmd.com/migraines-headaches/migraines-headaches-basics) or [weakness](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/tc/weakness-and-fatigue-topic-overview) may also occur. If any of these effects continue beyond 2 days or become bothersome, tell your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics) professional. Rarely, some people have symptoms such as [fainting](https://www.webmd.com/brain/understanding-fainting-basics), [dizziness](https://www.webmd.com/first-aid/understanding-dizziness-basics), [vision](https://www.webmd.com/eye-health/vision-basics) changes, or [ringing in the ears](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/understanding-tinnitus-basics) just after getting a [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) injection. Tell your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/video/what-is-the-aca) professional right away if you have any of these symptoms. Sitting or lying down may help, since these symptoms usually don't last long. Remember that this [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) has been prescribed because your health care professional has judged that the benefit to you is greater than the risk of side effects. Many people using this medication do not have serious side effects. Tell your health care professional right away if you have any serious side effects, including: mental/mood changes, numbness/tingling, [seizures](https://www.webmd.com/epilepsy/understanding-seizures-basics). A very serious [allergic reaction](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/allergic-reaction-causes) to this drug is rare. However, get medical help right away if you notice any symptoms of a serious [allergic reaction](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/anaphylaxis-15/slideshow-allergy-triggers), including: [rash](https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/common-rashes), [tongue](https://www.webmd.com/oral-health/picture-of-the-tongue)/throat), [trouble breathing](https://www.webmd.com/lung/breathing-problems-causes-tests-treatments). This is not a complete list of possible side effects. If you notice other effects not listed above, contact your health care professional. Contact the health care professional for medical advice about side effects. The following numbers do not provide medical advice, but in the US you may report side effects to the [Vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/healthtool-childhood-immunizations-guide) Adverse Event Reporting System (VAERS) at 1-800-822-7967. In Canada, you may call the Vaccine Safety Section at Public Health Agency of Canada at 1-866-844-0018. Precautions Before receiving this vaccination, tell your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics) professional if you are allergic to it; or to any other [vaccines](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation); or if you have any other [allergies](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/allergy-relief-10/slideshow-allergy-myths-facts). This product may contain inactive ingredients (such as latex found in some brands), which can cause allergic reactions or other problems. Talk to your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/video/what-is-the-aca) professional for more details. Before you receive this [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation), tell your health care professional your medical history, especially of: any fever, uncontrolled [seizures](https://www.webmd.com/epilepsy/understanding-seizures-basics) or other nervous system disorder (such as encephalopathy), history of [Guillain](https://www.webmd.com/brain/what-is-guillain-barre)-Barre syndrome, [immune system disorders](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/autoimmune-diseases) (such as due to [HIV](https://www.webmd.com/hiv-aids/understanding-aids-hiv-basics) infection, certain cancers such as [leukemia](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/lymphoma/understanding-leukemia-basics)/ [lymphoma](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/lymphoma/lymphoma-cancer), [cancer](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/health-check-cancer-risk/default.htm) or [radiation](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/what-to-expect-from-radiation-therapy) treatment), seizures (such as [epilepsy](https://www.webmd.com/epilepsy/ss/slideshow-epilepsy-overview) controlled by [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx), febrile seizures) or history of other nervous system disorders, vaccination history including previous reactions to any [vaccines](https://www.webmd.com/children/healthtool-childhood-immunizations-guide). During pregnancy, [flu vaccination](https://www.webmd.com/cold-and-flu/fact-sheet-vaccines) is usually recommended. Discuss the risks and benefits with your health care professional. It is unknown if this [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/healthtool-childhood-immunizations-guide) passes into [breast](https://www.webmd.com/women/picture-of-the-breasts) milk. Consult your health care professional before breast-feeding. Interactions [Drug interactions](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/video/vd-0801-atsp-12) may change how your [medications](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) work or increase your risk for serious side effects. This document does not contain all possible drug interactions. Keep a list of all the products you use (including prescription/nonprescription drugs and herbal products) and share it with your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics) professional. Do not start, stop, or change the dosage of any medicines without your doctor's approval. Overdose Not applicable. Not applicable. Store in the refrigerator. Do not freeze. Protect from light. Keep all [medications](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) away from children and pets. Do not flush medications down the toilet or pour them into a drain unless instructed to do so. Properly discard this product when it is expired or no longer needed. Consult your [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions) or local waste disposal company. Images Fluzone This medicine is a colorless, clear, currently using Fluzone High-Dose (PF) 240 Mcg/0.7 Ml IM Syringe Vaccine?
